awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSI: Lidar Radar Open Software Environment (LROSE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern radars and lidars are a diverse class of instruments, capable of detecting molecules, aerosols, birds, bats and insects, winds, moisture, clouds, and precipitation. Scientists and engineers use them to perform research into air quality and pollution, dangerous biological plumes, cloud physics, cloud extent, climate models, numerical weather prediction, road weather, aviation safety, severe convective storms, tornadoes, hurricanes, floods, and movement patterns of birds, bats and insects. Radars and lidars are critical for protecting society from high impact weather and understanding the atmosphere and biosphere, but they are complex instruments that produce copious quantities of data that pose many challenges for researchers, students, and instrument developers. This project will develop a new set of tools called the Lidar Radar Open Software Environment (LROSE) to meet these challenges and help address the 'big data' problem faced by users in the research and education communities. This project will open new avenues of scientific investigation, including data assimilation to improve weather forecasts, and help to maximize returns on NSF investments in weather and climate research by providing better software tools to researchers, students, and educators. Improving the effectiveness of NSF research will provide significant scientific and societal benefits through an improved understanding of many diverse scientific topics that are relevant to public safety, national defense, and the global economy.

The LROSE project will develop a 'Virtual Toolbox' with a set of software tools needed for a diverse set of scientific applications. LROSE will be packaged so that it can be run on a virtual machine (VM), either locally or in the cloud, and stocked with core algorithm modules for those typical processing steps that are well understood and documented in the peer-reviewed literature. LROSE will enable the user community to use the core toolset to develop new research modules that address the specific needs of the latest scientific research. Through the VM Toolbox and a core software framework, other developers of open-source radar software can then provide their own compatible software tools to the set. By combining the open source approach with recent developments in virtual machines and cloud computing, we will develop a system that is both highly capable and easy to run on virtually any hardware, without the complexity of a compilation environment. The LROSE project will build on existing prototypes and available software elements, while facilitating community development of new techniques and algorithms to distribute a suite of documented software modules for performing radar and lidar analysis. These modules will each implement accredited scientific methods referencing published papers. The infrastructure and modules will allow researchers to run standard procedures, thereby improving the efficiency and reproducibility of the analyses, and encourage researchers to jointly develop new scientific approaches for data analysis. The use of collaborative open source methods will lead to a suite of available algorithmic modules that will allow scientists to explore radar and lidar data in new, innovative ways. Researchers will benefit from the improved toolset for advancing understanding of weather and climate, leading to a positive outcome in the advancement of scientific knowledge and societal benefits.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed the Lidar Radar Open Software Environment (LROSE) by applying a collaborative open source approach between Colorado State University (CSU) and the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) to help to address the 'big data' problem faced by users in the radar and lidar research community. This project built on existing prototypes and available software elements, while facilitating community development of new techniques and algorithms. A primary objective of the project was to meet broader geoscience community needs through development, testing, and using newly developed software components and demonstrating their capabilities. 

To meet project goals, we had four major software releases over the course of the project entitled 'Blaze', 'Cyclone', 'Elle', and 'Topaz' which were named after different varieties of roses. Each release added more functionality and stability to the set of software tools available for the geoscience community to work with lidar and radar data. The project also led to publication of scientific papers on the use of lidar and radar data for scientific analysis, and multiple conference presentations describing the software and relevant applications to the broader scientific community. 

The final LROSE release of the project is called 'Topaz' (a bright hot pink rose) and encompasses six key toolsets that define a core lidar/radar workflow: Convert, Display, Quality Control, Grid, Echo, and Winds. Topaz focuses on high-quality, well-tested, well-maintained and well-documented key applications as 'building blocks', allowing users to assemble trusted, reproducible workflows to accomplish more complex scientific tasks. Topaz can be compiled in C++ programming language for native apps on Linux or Mac. Some support is available for some tools on Windows.

In the 'Convert' toolset, software was developed that can convert over 24 different radar and lidar formats to a common, self-describing NetCDF data format called CfRadial. The CfRadial format has metadata conventions that make it easy to manipulate the data in LROSE or other community tools. The Convert tools are the most widely used of the LROSE toolset as they are the prerequisite for subsequent data analysis in many existing radar open source software packages.

After conversion to CfRadial, the next step in a lidar or radar processing workflow is often to 'Display' the data and inspect the observations. We developed two tools called HawkEye and HawkEdit that are designed for efficient inspection and editing of remote sensing data. These software tools replace older software that is no longer possible to run on modern computers, and whose replacement was deemed a high priority by the user community.

Lidar and radar data usually has non-meteorological echoes due to signals from ground targets, bugs, birds, noise, and other data besides weather. To address this issue, we developed an extensive set of 'Quality Control' tools that can be used to remove unwanted data and can correct and calibrate the radar signals. These tools are essential for high quality signal processing and scientific analysis.

Typical lidar and radar data is collected by scanning an antenna to point at features of interest, but this native coordinate system is often inconvenient for many types of analysis. The 'Grid' tools can convert the data from its native, spherical coordinates to a regular grid which facilitates spatial and statistical analysis. The gridding software developed in this project also replaces older software that was used for many years but is no longer maintainable on modern computers.

After conversion, display, quality control, and gridding, the data is ready for many different types of scientific analysis. We developed many different tools in the 'Echo' and 'Wind' applications that operate on the precipitation data and Doppler velocity data collected by these complex instruments. These software tools can calculate hydrometeor properties, rain rates, three-dimensional winds, and many other useful products from the raw data.

The difficulty that users face in analyzing large complex datasets restricts the progress of scientific research. The complete set of LROSE tools in the Topaz release consists of over 435 applications that work together to reduce this complexity and aid in the processing and analysis of lidar and radar data. We also developed a new website at http://lrose.net that includes documentation, tutorials, and a user forum. This project enables research into air quality, dangerous biological plumes, cloud physics, cloud extent, climate models, numerical weather prediction, road weather, aviation safety, hazardous weather, and movement patterns of birds, bats and insects. This project has opened up new avenues of scientific investigation by providing better access to software tools for researchers, students, and educators. Improving the effectiveness of radar and lidar research will continue to enhance our understanding of many diverse topics in the future.
